Hard at work

Here is an overview of a few of the projects that our founders have contributed to in the past.

Some are big, some are small, some are open-source, some are government-funded, but they all carry the same mission: to make data analysis and visualization simple, straight-forward, and sexy.

DataViva

DataViva was a joint effort between the co-founders of Datawheel and the Office of Strategic Priorities for the government of Minas Gerais, Brazil. It makes labor and export data for the entirity of Brazil accessable in a public, easy to use visualization tool.

Through more than 100 million interactive visualizations, users can learn valuable insights and knowledge regarding the entire formal sector of Brazil.

Contributing Members:

César Hidalgo

Alexander Simoes

Dave Landry

D3plus

When the team began creating web platforms for visualizing large disaggregate datasets, it became clear that there was need for a tool to quickly and effectively visualize the datasets at hand.

Enter D3plus, the open-source love child of Datawheel co-founders Alexander Simoes and Dave Landry. D3plus acts as an extension to the wildly popular D3js libary, making gorgeous data visualizations accessible with only a few lines of code.

Contributing Members:

Alexander Simoes

Dave Landry

The Observatory of Economic Complexity

The Observatory of Economic Complexity was developed by Alex Simoes and Cesar Hidalgo at MIT, and visualizes over 50 years of UN Comtrade data. It is a tool that allows users to quickly compose a visual narrative about countries and the products they exchange.

The site provides new ways of viewing world trade data by introducing new statistical measures and a new type of network visualization, The Product Space.

Contributing Members:

César Hidalgo

Alexander Simoes

Dave Landry

With great data, comes great responsibility.
